head.supplied: ¶ It will sadden you deeply, honoured Professor, that our noble friend J. Bracebridge Wilson has passed away!. What a great loss for us individually! What a great loss also for the study of Australia...

div.p:
The letter is undated. A newspaper clipping from the Argus of 24 October 189, p. 6 is enclosed, reporting the funeral in Geelong of John Bracebridge Wilson on the previous afternoon (i.e. 23.October 1895), which M attended. It is dated on the assumption that the letter was written on the date M clipped the article.
Es wird Sie tief betrüben, verehrter Herr Professor, dass unser edler Freund J. Bracebridge Wilson dahin geschieden ist! Welch ein grosser Verlust für uns individuell! Welch ein grosser Verlust auch für die australische Algen-Kunde. Ich kann noch gar nicht den Gedanken realisiren, dass ich nie wieder Briefe von ihm erhalten werde, denn mein erstes persönliches Zusammenkommen mit ihm war 1858 , in welchen Jahr ich eine Menge junger Coniferen und anderer Bäume für die Umgebung des grossen dann erbauten Schulgebäudes lieferte. Er ist an einer Hepatitis mit Complicationen zu Grunde gegangen. Ich mache biographische Mittheilungen an Mr. Murray, jetzt der Chef der Pflanzlichen Abtheilung im britischen Museum, damit er über unseren unvergleichlichen Geelong Freund einen Nekrolog für die Linné-Gesellschaft schreibe.

div.p:
It will sadden you deeply, honoured Professor, that our noble friend J. Bracebridge Wilson has passed away!. What a great loss for us individually! What a great loss also for the study of Australian algae. I cannot yet realise that I will never again receive a letter from him, since my first personal meeting with him was in 1858 , in which year I supplied a large number of young conifers and other trees for the surroundings of the large school building then built.
Geelong Grammar School.
He perished from hepatitis with complications. I reported biographically to Mr Murray now the head of the plant department in the British Museum,
George Robert Milne Murray succeeded W. Curruthers as Keeper of Botany at the British Museum in 1895. so that he would write an obituary of our incomparable Geelong friend for the Linnean Society.
An unsigned obituary of Wilson was published in
Proceedings of the Linnean Society of London
(1895-6), pp. 48-9.
